title: Pomelo festival in Chai Nat
text:
Pomelo festival in Chai Nat 3 Sep 2015 at 03:47 110 viewed 0 comments NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: PICHAYA SVASTI - + From Sept 11 until Sept 20, the "32nd Khao Taeng-Kwa Pomelo" festival will take place in the Hin Riang area in front of Chai Nat Provincial Hall, Muang district, Chai Nat province. The fair is aimed at promoting the famous khao taeng-kwa pomelo, boosting the sale of local farm produce, plants and handicrafts and supporting local tourism. 
Khao taeng-kwa pomelo from Chai Nat. 
Activities will include the sale of pomelos and local products and demonstrations of pomelo preserving. 
After the fair, participants can visit local attractions, such as a bird park, a museum, the Chao Phraya Dam, Wat Khlong Makham Thao and nine other famous temples. Contact the Tourism Authority of Thailand's Suphan Buri Office which also oversees tourism in Chai Nat on 035-525-867 or 035-525-880. Exhibit on Three Bandits 
From Sept 11 until Sept 13, Suphan Buri province will host the "Legend Of Suphan Buri's Bandits" exhibition at the Suphan Buri National Museum in Muang district, Suphan Buri. 
The exhibit will present the stories of the province's three most infamous bandits named Sua Fai, Sua Bai and Sua Mahesuan. The three were said to have wanted to be decent people, but were forced to become bandits. 
There will be exhibitions, discussions, retro-style activities and movie screenings. Call the TAT's Suphan Buri Office on 035-525-867 or 035-525-880. Boat Festival in Kanchanaburi 
From Sept 26 until Sept 28, the "Boat Floating For Driving Away Bad Luck" tradition will be held near the Samsob area where three rivers join in tambon Nong Lu, Sangkhla Buri district of Kanchanaburi province. 
The highlight will be the release of a large bamboo boat for worshipping angels. Other activities will be the release of gigantic lanterns and merit making in front of a model of Bodhgaya Pagoda at Wat Wang Wiwekaram. 
This Mon tradition lasts for three days starting from the day before to the day after the Full Moon day of the 10th lunar month. It was inspired by the legend that the angels saved a boat carrying Mon monks from Sri Lanka back to Bago, now in Myanmar, on their mission to improve Buddhism in Bago centuries ago. 
Before the days of the ceremony, local villagers will make paper flags and umbrellas and prepare ritual items while a number of men will gather at the temple to build the boat from bamboo and decorate it with colourful paper. 
From the first night to the dawn of the second day, all will come to the temple to decorate the boat with flags and umbrellas. They will place ritual objects such as bananas, sugar cane, rice, desserts and flowers in the middle of the boat and make a wish for bad luck and evil things to go away. Later, they will listen to monks' chanting to give them blessings. On the final day, the villagers will gather in a parade to release huge flying lanterns, sing, dance and release the boat onto the water in the Samsob area. 
After joining the ceremony, visitors can visit the Mon Bridge, the Three Pagodas Pass and the abandoned Wat Somdet that has an old beautiful ordination hall opposite the former town of Sangkhla Buri which was submerged by water due to the construction of Vajiralongkorn Dam from 1979-1984. Call the TAT's local office on 034-511-200. Rare phenomenon in the Northeast 
Until the end of this month, tourists are welcome to Lamduan Rapid in Nam Yuen district, Ubon Ratchathani province, to see almost 100,000 tiny shrimps parading on rocks by the stream towards the Lan Phan Ru area and then Phanom Dongrak Mountain for mating and egg laying. They usually travel from around 9pm until 4am each day in August and September. Call the TAT's Ubon Ratchathani Office on 045-243-770.
